react.translation[0].definitions[0].defi: to behave in a particular way or show a particular emotion because of something that has happened or been said
react.translation[0].definitions[0].exam: She reacted very badly (=was very upset) when her parents split up.
You have to react quickly to circumstances.
How did Wilson react to your idea?
He reacted angrily to the suggestion that he had lied.
The government reacted by declaring all strikes illegal.
react.translation[0].definitions[1].defi: if a chemical substance reacts, it changes when it is mixed with another chemical substance
react.translation[0].definitions[1].exam: The calcium reacts with sulphur in the atmosphere.
react.translation[0].definitions[2].defi: if prices or financial markets react to something that happens, they increase or decrease in value because of it
react.translation[0].definitions[2].exam: Oil prices reacted sharply (=reacted a lot) to news of the crisis in the Middle East.
The market reacted favourably to the announcement.
react.translation[0].definitions[3].defi: to become ill when a chemical or drug goes into your body, or when you eat a particular kind of food
react.translation[0].definitions[3].exam: Quite a lot of children react badly to antibiotics.
react.translation[0].note_box[0].section: Do you react badly to criticism?
The prime minister reacted angrily to these accusations.
Scott reacted strongly when he felt he was being treated unjustly.
The goalkeeper had to react quickly.
We want versatile people who react positively to change.
The United States has reacted cautiously to the offer.
She reacted instinctively and reached for her gun.
react.translation[1].definitions[0].defi: to start rising or falling in price, level etc because of something that has happened or that has been said
react.translation[1].definitions[0].exam: The stock market reacted favorably to the announcement.
Oil prices reacted only mildly to news of the cut in Saudi production.
